awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Ecological Context of Complex Society Emergence
awd_abstract_narration:
Paleoclimate research seeks to understand the role of environmental change on human society. Archaeological remains provide a long-term perspective on human-environment interaction not available from other sources. This project will contribute to this interdisciplinary field of science by reconstructing the cultural and environmental factors responsible for a 9000-year vegetation history of a valley in southern Peru.  This information will allow scientists to model the effects of future climate change, human impact, and social responses to that change.  This research began with a chance finding in 2012 during archaeological excavations in a floodplain in the Chincha valley of southern Peru.  While excavating in a farm field near a 2300-year-old archaeological site to better assess prehistoric agricultural practices, researchers found evidence of wet and marshy conditions five kilometers from the ocean during the middle Holocene circa 7000 -1500 years ago. This was quite unexpected because archaeologists and paleo-climate specialists had assumed the area to have been open desert prior to human occupation.  Previous scientific consensus was that the desert was irrigated around 3000 years ago by people using canals drawn from the deeply entrenched rivers that course through the valley.  Additional work found similar patterns of hydromorphic (waterlogged) soils and evidence of the use of artificial drainage canals.  Analyses of ancient seeds, pollen, plant microfossils, and diatoms (fossil algae) confirmed evidence of a lush landscape back to 9000 years ago that included plants such as cattails, sedges, and rushes. This project's systematic scientific research will confirm, modify, or reject the hypothesis of a paleo-wetland. The project incorporates students from two US universities who will work with students in Peru, thereby increasing cross-border training and seeding future collaboration.  These early career researchers will learn advanced laboratory techniques to reconstruct past environments, including state-of -the-art techniques in ground-penetrating radar and archaeological methods.
 
Stretching from Chile to California, the Pacific desert watershed is home to very dense human populations today and has provided favored locations to live for millennia. These areas are also some of the richest agricultural lands in the world.  A full appreciation of their environmental and cultural histories is vital, not least because fresh water is the limiting factor in population growth and agricultural productivity. To properly understand the intricate history of vegetation, water, irrigation, geology, and human settlement, this project will obtain data from a representative swath of land in the entire Chincha Valley of coastal Peru.  The vegetation, geological, and geomorphological history will be meticulously reconstructed.  Project participants will measure the ground water levels over millennia.  Correlations of cultural and environmental records with El Nino events, tsunamis, tectonic events, and other natural processes will shed light on the relationship between cultural adaptations and environmental change.  Buried archeological sites and canals will be detected with ground-penetrating radar.  At its conclusion, the project will provide a highly detailed understanding of the human-environment history of a key Pacific watershed drainage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Scientific results:

 

Our major scientific goal was to understand the effects of El Niño events on human settlements and agriculture in the Chincha Valley of southern Peru during the mid to late Holocene.  Our research was designed to do a fine-grained analysis of the archaeological and vegetation history of this valley. We documented the changes in climate, presence of El Niño events such as major flooding, and how this impacted the nature of human land use over time. We analyzed 66 soil samples from the last 4000 years to collect ancient pollen and fossilized plant cells known as phytoliths. We demonstrated that the original vegetation of the valley was composed of at least seven tree species and a mosaic of wetlands, meadows and sand dunes. Around 1000 BCE, the modern El Niño regime began with periodic heavy flooding and massive sedimentation into the mid and lower valley. Between 750 and 500 BCE, half of the tree species disappeared, cultivated plants dominated, and invasive species were numerous. Deep-rooted trees were selected for at the expense of shallow-rooted ones. At the beginning of urban life that corresponded to a population maximum circa 500 BCE, trees were absent from the record, while domesticated plants and useful wild plants flourished. With the collapse of urban society after 200 BCE, tree species returned to the landscape. Domesticated and useful plants flourished. During the second population maximum of the Prehispanic period circa AD 1400, trees again disappeared, and a more restricted set of domesticated and useful plants dominated the record and the farmers leaned towards more single cropping and intensive agricultural techniques. 

 

Our work shows that El Niño was actually beneficial to human land use in the beginning of the modern cycle 3000 years ago. It illustrates the sophisticated use of indigenous knowledge in dealing with climatic shifts. The floods provided consistent fertilization of the fields with nutrient-rich basalt-derived sediments. This provided for year-round agriculture in this coastal area. Furthermore, El Niño changes in the ocean provided for periodic windfalls of marine resources, particularly small fish that could be salted, dried and stored for long periods. At the end of the first urban phase, however, the effects of El Niño turned negative. The massive sedimentation lowered the water table relative to the land surface. This promoted desertification more typical of the modern landscape. Most significantly, El Niño floods entrenched irrigation canals in the mid valley making them ineffective. Populations responded by moving their settlements closer to the ocean shore where groundwater levels were adequate to maintain intensive irrigation agriculture.

 

Broader impacts:

 

Our primary social goal was to provide Peruvian and US students an opportunity to work on an fascinating STEM project. Archaeology is an enjoyable field discipline. Students are introduced to scientific logic, statistical reasoning, creating and testing theoretically-informed models, and the joy of discovery. We were particularly concerned about underrepresented and economically disadvantaged students. We provided hands-on field work for multiple students. We introduced state-of-the-art technology in the lab and in the field to these students and young professionals in Peru. This experience teaches marketable skills both in and outside of scientific careers. We believe it is a wonderful way to bring students into STEM. We provided the context for intercultural interaction among our young Peruvian and US colleagues and students. We provided the data for graduate doctoral theses, as well as professional certificates of Peruvian students at no financial cost to them. One Peruvian student is now in our graduate program in Florida. We trained undergraduates and graduates in our laboratory in Tampa. We supported several undergraduates from the United states to participate directly in our research in the laboratory and the field. 

 

We structured our field program to provide maximum benefit to Peruvian students of modest means to pursue their degree completion. The custom in Peru is that BA students have to pay the costs of their capstone field projects to obtain data for their professional certification. We instead covered the entire cost of their project. We provided stipends to these students, provided all required logistical support for their research, insured the highest scientific quality work, paid for their permits and allowed them to use data from the project for their professional certification. 

 

We furthermore collaborated with local authorities and media influencers to produce compelling short videos on the archaeology of the Chincha area. Our university partner, Universidad Nacional Mayor San Marcos in Lima, also has produced several excellent shorts on our research.
